〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
It may be the manner of his motion is implyed in 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , but if the Doctor should deny it, I could not prove it to him. Many of the like instances might be given: and if I had not been taught, I should as little have known how the Gods did move: which is excellently described by Ronsard in his poem upon Q. Margaret.

Thus he describes Pasithea one of Venus's Graces coming from Heaven.
The young and all Divine Pasithea
The Skyes abandon'd her command t' obey,
The ayre gave place unto her, and the winde
Thorough the vast regions blow'd her up behinde.
She stoop'd descending in a suddain flight,
Cleaving the clouds, as in the silent night
Far off there in a shining track is spi'd
A falling star betwixt two ayres to glide.
And afterwards he describes the Queens dancing at the Ballet Royall.
Locking his hand in her's the King did lead
The dance, and her who did not seem to tread,
But as she had no feet, she in her pace
Swimm'd as she mov'd with a celestial grace.
Man heavy treads, and by his gate doth show
The dull allyance he to earth does owe:
But Gods do flie, and unconsin'd to pace
Prove their eternal and spiritual race.
When the Lavolto was of Provence danc'd,
The King with this his sister Grace advanc'd
In a grave sweetness, nimbly following She
With ayrie motion 'bout the Hall did flee.
What remains of this discourse is taken up in a mistake of mine, which being neither voluntary, nor greatly material, I am the less concerned in acknowledging that I did him wrong imposing upon him that he should say Empusa came to be attributed to the boyes play. He said comes to be attributed, &c. As I have represented it now in the text, which my hast did not then permit me to consider so thoroughly. I acknowledged that the boye's play might be so called, but that it was so called I desired proofe. I excepted against Holyoke and Thomas (for Iunius hath no such thing: and the two dictionaries aforesaid deceived the Doctor, for they said Ascoliasmus Ludus Empusa Iun. fox to thy hole: and he presently thought Iunius had said Ludus Empusa was the same game with fox to thy hole.) I excepted against them as no Authors, but vocabularies. I confess they may in some sense be called Authors, as the Doctor may be called the Author of that Phrase adducis mall • um, which term will not make for his advantage, when
any man shall bestow it upon him: I took it in that sense which Lancilotus Pasius (to whom I had then regard) did take it in, when he disputes whether Isidorus, Priscian, &c. be to be acknowledged Authors? Lib. 2. c. 34. Authores voc • et vocandos censeo, quorum dicta sequamur ad instituendam eruditionem; and afterwards, Authores propriè Scriptores, ut Homerus, accipiendi; qui fuerunt ante observationem artis Grammaticae, quorum dicta observave • e posteriores aliqui ad artem sermonis, et hoc pertinet ad Grammaticos: aliqui aemulati sunt, ut poetae, atque alii, unde & ipsi authorum nomine gaudent. Ergo cùm dicunt aliqui Authorem Priscianum, (ne alios hoc genus recenseam) animadvertant, an ab eo sit Authoritas quem sequatur eruditorum consensus, qui in its • Grammatied nititur aliorum exemplis: qua causae est, quod ubi caret exemplo iterum at qu • iterium exploditur; Praecipue à Vallà taxatur Nonius, non dicam de Servio & Do • ato quos constat authoritate muniri poetarum, oratorum, historicorum. Quid? quod Plinius in Grammatice, Charisius, Probus, Diomedes, & majoris existimationis Gellius, citant Scriptores: nulla alia profectò de causa, nisi ut dignoscantur ministri à dominis; ii sunt Grammatici, hi verò authores. Which words since they are highly rational, I see no cause why I should recede from my former thoughts: doth any man take the single Authority of Thomas, or Holyoke, for a sufficient proofe in Latin. It seems the Doctor doth; I advise him therefore betimes to sue out a writ of Priviledge, and remove his case from Westminster School to the Vniversity, for there it is so far from being valued, that it is a whipping matter for any in the upper forms to alledge them. You see what a difference there is betwixt Classique and Classical Authors. He asks me what is the difference betwixt 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and Vocabularium? This is not so perplexing a Query, as the Doctor took it to be. There is no difference in the name; but there is a great difference in our manner of citing them: I cite Pollux as a Vocabulary, he refers to Thomas and Holyoke as Authors. He would not cite Pollux, because he did not think him to be a prophet: yet I favourably think the Doctor did prophetically bring against Mr. Hobs that argumentum ad hominem. Whether the Authors I have cited all along be to the purpose, I refer to the discreet readers judgement: I doubt not but he will concur with me in this, that the Doctor hath felt the force of them to the purpose: and particularly as to Ascoliasmus I could not but speak of it, for without doing so I could neither have found Ludus Empusae in Iunius, nor fox to thy hole in Rider or Thomos.

div.head: Sect. 7.
div.p:
• . I Now come to the Doctors last and greatest
• riumph, at which I cannot but stand
〈◊〉 admiration, when I consider he hath not got the victory. Had the Doctor been pleased to have conversed with some of the Fifth Form in Westminster School (for he needed not to have troubled the Learned Master) he might have been better informed then to have exposed himself thus.

Mr. Hobbes had said, A Ma • k, or of some put instead of it,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is a mark with an hot Iron, is visible; if visible, then it hath quantity; and consequently may be divided into parts innumerable. After that the Doctor had reflected upon the wit of the argument (whereas he ought to have replyed to the Antecedent: the reason being valid, It is visible, therefore its divisible) He is pleased to play the Drol thus upon that saying, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
is a mark without an hot Iron.
• Prethee tell me good Tho. before we leave this point (O the wit of a Divinity Doctor!) who it was told thee that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 was a mark with an hot Iron? Dr. V •
for 'tis a notion I never heard till now, (and do not believe it yet) Never believe him that told thee that lye; for as sure as can be, he did it to abuse thee. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifies a distinctive point in writing made with a Pen or Quill, not a mark made with an hot Iron, such as they brand Rogues withal; and accordingly 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , distinguo, interstinguo, are often so used. It is also used of a Mathematical point, or somewhat else that is very small, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a moment, or the like. What should come in your Cap, to make you think that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifies a mark or brand with an hot iron? I perceive where the businesse lies; 'twas 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ran in your minde when • you talked of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and because the words are somewhat alike, you jumbled them both together, according to your usual care and accuratenesse, as if they had been the same.

p.hi:
When I read this, I cannot but be astonished at the Doctors confidence, and appla • d him who said, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That the Doctor should never hear that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifies a mark with an hot iron, is a manifest argument of his ignorance: But that he should advise Mr. Hobbes not to believe his own readings, or any mans else that should tell him it did signifie any such thing, is a piece of notorious impudence. That 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
signifies a distinctive point in writing made with a Pen or Quill, (is a Pen one thing, and a Quill another to write with?) no body denies. But it must be withall acknowledged that it Signifyes many things else. I know the Doctor is a good Historian (else he should not presume to object the want of History to another) let him tell us how long • goe it is, since men have made use of Pens or Quils in writing; for if that invention be of no long standing, this signification must also be such; and so it could not be that from any allusion thereunto the Mathematicians used it for a point. Another thing I would • ain know of this great Historian; how long ago 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
began to signifie interpugno? for if the Mathematicks were studied before the mystery of Pointing was found our (as shall be proved, when ever it shall please the Doctor out of his no-reading to maintaine the contrary.) Then the Mathematical use thereof should have been named before the Grammatical. And if this word be translatitio • s, and that Sciences were the effect of long contemplation, the names used herein ar •
borrowed from commons talk; Mr. Hobbes did well to say that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 precedaneous • y▪ to that indivisible signification, which it afterwards had, did signifie a visible mark, made by an hot Iron, or the like. And in this procedure, he did no more then any
man would have done, who considers that all our knowledge proceeds from our 〈◊〉 ; as also that words do primarily signifie things obvious to sense and only second •
rily, such as men call
〈◊〉 .

This occasion leads me to a further consideration of the word. Hesychi • s (of whom It is said, Legendus est non t • nquam 〈◊〉 , sed tanquam jus • us Author) Interprets
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is a point or prick of a greater of lesser size, made with any thing. So 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifies to prick or mark with any thing in any manner, and hath no impropriated signification in it self, but according to the writer that useth it. Thus in a Gr •• mmarian
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifies to distinguish by pointing often, sometimes, even in them, it is the same with 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : sometimes it signifies to • et a mark, that something is wanting in that place, which marks were called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . In matters of policy
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
signifies to disallow, because they used to put a 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 )▪ before his name who was either disapproved, or to be mulcted. In punishments it signifies to mark or brand, whereof that of an hot Iron in most usual in Authors, because most practised by the Ancients. And the mark which the T • rks and others do imprint without burning may be said 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; at likewise in Herodian that term is given to the ancient Britains, of whom he sayes 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Thus Horses that were branded with 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) were said 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : was a term of Law; when any mans land was morgaged the Creditor did erect a Pillar ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) as 〈◊〉 token of the mo • ga • e, so the field became 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as the contrary 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . So Pollux.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 seems to have been taken for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , hence 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in Eustathius, Pollux, yea, Hesychi • s, as I have elsewhere cited him. The Sea also is said 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in Eustahitus upon 〈◊〉 . 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . As to the Grammaticall use (supposing punctation not to have been in use in Aristotles time,) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in his Rhetorick torick signifies no more then to point as children do with a Fescu • , where no impression remains. It doth also signifie the making of a real point in wri • ing, hence 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or marked with points on every side, was used in the books of Plate
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as L • erti • s in his life tels us; it stood for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , (whence your
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or collections of sentences) as L. N. in Latine stood for Laudabilis nota. But farther Epiphanius in his book De ponderibus & mensuris, makes use I conceive of
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for the several punct •• ions in writing, as the notes of Aspiration and Leviga •••• , Apostrophus, Hyphen, &c. with which he saith 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Nazia • zen in his Letter ad notarium giving him directions how to write, biddeth him 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

Thus in its Origine
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 doth signifie a visible mark or brand, with an hot iron, or the like; And that that must be the proper signification to 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is proper to 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , none but such as D • Wallis can doubt. And in it's descendants it is no lesse evident; for from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 comes Stig •• sus, which signifies branded, or marked: Vit • lli •••
cicatrice stig •• sus, not stigmatosus: so Pliny in his Epistles, as Robert Stephen cites it. And 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (the derivative of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which signifies any mark, as well as a brand, even such remain after stripes, being black and blue) was a Nick-name imposed upon the Grammarian Nicanor,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . And though we had not any examples of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 being used in this sense, yet from thence for any men to argue against it (but he who will know no more then Stephen tels him) is madnesse, unless he will deny that any word hath lost its right signification, and is used only (by the Authors we have, though neither the Doctor nor I have read all them) in its A •• logicall signification.

I have alwayes been of opinion, that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signified a single p • i • t, big or little, i •
〈…〉
the letter not, had signified a single point, had such been used. And from the common use of it for a point made any way, (upon severall occasions severally, but a point it became
〈◊〉 used, by Philosophers, Mathematicians, and Grammarians. I could give grounds for this conjecture, and not be so impertinent as the Docter in his Sermon, where he told us that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 was not in Ho •• r; that from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 came •• brius; that Subrietas was not bad Latine; that Sabrius was once (as I remember) in Tully. Is this to speake Suitably to the oracles of God, or rather to lash out into idle wordes? Hath the Doctor any ground to thinke these are not impertinencyes? Or are we, poor mortalls, accountable for such idle words as fall from us in private discourses; whilest these Embassadours of heaven droll in the pulpit without any danger of an after-reckoning?

But I procced to a further survey of the Doctors intolerable ignorance. Nis charge in the end of [his] Schoole-Master's rant, is, that he should remember 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
are not all one. I complained before that he had not cited Robert Stephen
• right: now I must tell him that he hath been negligent in the reading of Henry Shephen; for in him he might have found that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 was sometimes all one with
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , though there be no example to him wherein 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is used for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Hath
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈◊〉 (as Stephen rightly cireth it) in his Scutum Herculis

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . So Scholi • stes, Ioannes 〈◊〉
upon the place, a man, who (it I may use the Doctors phrase) was as good a criticke, as the Geometry professors?

Thus much for the Doctor: to the understanding Reader, I say that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , used, for burning with an hot, iron; a Mac • cab. 9. 11. where speaking of Antiochus's lamen
•• ble death, his body p • trifying and breeding wormes, he is said 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , being pained as if he had been pricked with hot irons. And that this is the meaning of that elegant writer, shall be made good against the Doctor, when he shall please to defend the vulgar interpretation. P •• sanias, in Baeo • icis, speaking of Epaminondas, who had taken a
〈◊〉 belonging to the Sicyonians called Phae ••• , wherein were many B •• otisn fugitives, who ought by law to have been put to death, saith, he dismissed them under other names, giving them onely a brand or mark.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . It is true 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is here put adverbially. but that doth not alter the case. Another example of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 used in this sense is in the collections our of Diodorus Siculus lib. 34. As they are to be found at the end of his workes, and as Photius hath transcribed them into his Biliothaca. He saith that the Romans did buy multitudes of servants and employ them in Sicily;
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . These are the words but of 〈◊〉 Author, but ought to pas • e for the Judgèment of two, seeing Photius, by inserting them, hath made them his own. Again Zoneras in the third • ome of his History, in the life of the Emperour Theophi •• s, saith, that when Theophanes and another Monke had reproved the said Emperour for demolishing images, he took and Stigmatized each of them with twelve lambickes, in their faces,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . A place so evident, that I know
not what the Doctor can reply; it being 〈◊〉 with what the 〈◊〉 Author saith in the life of Irene,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . If the Doctor object that he is a Moderne Authour, he will never be able to render him so inconsiderable as Adriqnus 〈◊〉 Nomenclator, Thomos ••
and Ride • . If any will deny that he writes good Greek, Hieronymus We ••• s will tell them, his onely fault is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , redundancy in words, and not the use of bad ones.

Besides, it is the judgement of a great Master of the Greek tongue, that Stigmata, non tam puncta • psa, quàm 〈◊〉 veriet •• superfici • m Graci vocaveru •• . I need not I suppose name him, so great a Critick as the Doctor cannot be ignorant of him.

div.p:
Against this all that the Doctor saith is either false or grounded upon such mistakes, as that ungenerous resolution of his never to acknowledge, makes me suspect for voluntary. What Mr. Hobbes's argument was you have seen in the Letter, where he cannot except against the state of the question, it being taken out of himself 〈◊〉
correct. P. 28. All that Mr. Hobbes said, was that for
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
some do substitute
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is a mark with an 〈◊〉 . I did so understand this saying of his as if he had annexed those words with an hot iron, to explain, not to determine and restrain the signification of
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Which favour I allow the Doctor when he saith 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) is a mark with an hot iron. For 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is not onely any sort of mark, as upon the Dragons in H •
• ied afore-cited, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Eus • ath. histor. Ismen. l. 2. So 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Cantic. 1. 10. And in the collections of Theodotus at the end Clem. Alexandr.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . And Grog • r.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (citane Budaeo) So Arria • s de rebus Iudic.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
(I • dis) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . And Aristotl • Histor. Animal. l. 7. 976. calls the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , those marks that are born with and hereditary to some Families, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . But also the numeral 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which remark the Doctor did omit in his Arithmatick, because it was not • ound to be in Stephen, of those All •
sufficient Authors which he deals in. And thus that Pseudo-Master of Westminster School might as well have shewed the Doctor how 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 might be made without an hot iron, as well as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . I give the same allowance to that saying of his, that it is a brand with
〈◊〉 hot iron, when they mark a Slave or Rascal. Dispunct. p. 43. For else branding is not alwayes dishonourable. Giphanius observ. Ling. Lat. no •• s that 〈◊〉 calls the worst of Servants extrema not a serv • s, whence he collects that they had different marks, and that there were others melioris not • . Nay in its original, whether we deduce it from the Thracians, (as the common opinion doth) or from the Egyptians from whence it was propagated to the Assyrian Priests of Astacte, (whence I would bring it) it was hon • urable, Herodotus l. 3. saith, that amongst the Thracian Dames 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . So amongst the Britaines
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
was a piece of Gallantry. Of this opinion was Dion Chrysost ••
in his first Oration de ser ••• t; Wherein he asserts that one 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , might be 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Which when one thought absurd, he asked him if he had ever been in Thrace: he answered, yes. Then he demands again, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , As for the Egyptians it was a part of their Priests Initiation: Of this (I conceive Prudentius
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . 〈…〉 may have spoken▪
〈…〉
Ac •• minut • s ing • runt 〈◊〉 ,
His membra pergant utere; 〈◊〉 igniverint,
Quamcun
que partem corporis servens nota
Stigmirit, hane fic consecratam praedicant.
Unto this (I likewise conceive,) was it all • ded in the Old Law Levis. 19. 28. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . They should not stigmatize themselves, or make any such marks upon their bodies, as the Egyptians and Assyrians did. And in the Primitive times there wanted not those who would expound that of Iohn, that Christ should baptize
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , of this way of
〈◊〉 : and thereupon in baptism
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Hereunto alludeth Apuleins (or rather expresseth this custome of initiation) in Metam. l. 11. The Goddess told him that one Mithi • s was divino quodam stellarum consortio ipsi conjunctus: now this was the Priest who was to initiate him and carry him through the confines of • eath, & quatour elementa. Martial in another case saith Et 〈◊〉 linunt stella • am splen • a fr •• tem. Thence Pythagoras had it, thence Epimenides of whom Hesychius Milestus tells us that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Whence came the proverb 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as Me •• sius excellantly observes upon the place. So the Priests of Astacte Lucian (de deâ Syrid) saith, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . This was my apprehension of Mr. Hobs his words at first, which since he hath owned in his last reply (p. 15.) it is no longer • to be doubted. And though his words as they lay in the text at first had been suspicious? (though who could ever suspect a person of such parts and abilities, who had given such a proof of his abilities in Greek by translating Thucydides, and illustrating him with Maps, that neither will the Doctor be able to equal him in the like performance, or bring the Author thereof into dis-repute through his cavils?) yet now there is not any can impose upon him such an intendment without being guilty of for • ery. Which leads me 〈◊〉 to a just censure of what Dr. Wallis (that tender-fronted Theo •• gue!) saith both concerning Mr. Hobs and me.

Dr. W. I said, among other things, that you mistooke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : it was this, not that, signified a marks with an hot iron. Your reply confesses that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 doth so signifie; but undertakes to prove that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : are all one: and your journey-man comes in to help you.

What Mr. Hobs said at first I have already declared: It is true, Dr. Wallis did tell him (and that in
〈…〉
) how he mistook 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; but Mr. Hobs did never acknowledge any such thing: for though 〈◊〉 signifie a mark with an hot iron, yet it doth not follow that they are one and the same thing; because that signification i •
general, and they have, besides that general import, a particular distinctive signification, as have 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . So that (besides the Doctors ignorance) there was no reason to charge him with that mistak •
and jumble, or with want of accuratenesse, whereas he was more subtile and understanding then our Professour. Well! but the Doctor saith Mr. Hobs, in his reply confesses that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 doth so signifie. Yes! hear his own words! (P. 15.)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 doth no more signifie a brand with an hot iron, then 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
made also with an hot iron. They have both one common theme 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which does not signifie
〈◊〉
nor interpungo, nor inur •
(for all your Lexicon) but notam impri •• ere, or pungendo not are, WITHOUT any restriction to burning or punching. I hope you are now satisfied what a Conf • sion Mr. Hobs hath made in his last reply: you shall next see what he intanded to prove, but that my Letter did casually intervene, and so saved him that labour. Our Doctor saith he under •• es to prove that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈◊〉 all one.
Which is as true, as that I come in to 〈…〉
W ••• I saw that in Italick,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
are all one. I supposed it had been the assertion of Mr. Hobs and my self, and that he had therefore put a different character, because the sentence was not his. After a strict enquiry into what Mr. Hobs had delivered, I could not finde any such thing: that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 doth simply signifie a mark, he confesses, that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifies a point visible (which is a kinde of) mark, he doth likewise grant. He doth further say, that it is No lesse proper to say that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is •
mark (a certain mark is a mark; and indefinitum aequivales particulari) with a • hot iron, then to say the same of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , (which is also a certain mark.) These are the things he sayes, and if he said any more, or what might contradict these, I am confident I never came in to his help; and the Doctor hath acquitted me in the next page (though he would not in this) p. 44. If I understand him, he was alwayes of opinion that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
and
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
were not all one.

I have further examined my own Letter, to see what grounds he could have there to •• rge upon me such a proposition; as he had 〈◊〉 reasons from my own positive assertion, to pronounce, that I was alwayes of another judgement. The onely places that might give him occasion to say so, are these two: The first, where I say, that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is sometimes all one with
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which he might have found in Stephen, although he could not finde in him any example whereby to prove the use of
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . This I did there show out of Hesiod: which place I would have so far considered, as that we forge •
not how the Scholiast expounding 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 by 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 can hardly be understood to construe or explain obscurum per obscurius, the 〈◊〉 acception of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 by taking
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in a more unco •• h and improper sense: It seemes therefore highly probable that in the Scholiast's time the use of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for a visible point, was allowable (such as are the Spo • s upon Dragons, in which sense 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 are frequently used not onely by Oppian, but also Aeschy •• s, as your picti Aga • hyr •• , picti Geloni, virgati Da • ae in Latine) and the use of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in that sense, for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is demonstrated. And consequently as the Master bade the boy remember the difference between
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; so I may justly desire the Doctor to finde out the difference in that place of Hesiod's. But all this doth not give him cause to say that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
are all one. The next place is where I say (not to the Doctor but reader) that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
is used for a burning with an hot iron. But from hence he could not infer that I said 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
were all one; for, I have already shewed how both might be used to signifie a burne with an hot iron, and yet they might retaine their specificall significations still, and so continue differenced. And secondly had I taken there 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ( 〈◊〉 I did) 〈◊〉
a brand with an hot iron, yet it could not from such an use of the word be inferred, that they were simply all one: but that in the places cited they were so: which is but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Now all that I told the reader (to shew there was no such vast irreconcileable difference betwixt the two words) was That
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
is used for a burning with an hot iron. By this time you see not onely what Mr. Hobs, and what I said, but also what credit is to be given to the Do •• r. Now I come to examine what the Doctor hath brought by way of exception against the proofe Mr. Hobs, and I brought for such acceptation of the word.

My argument was this, that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 was descended from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which signified to marks with an hot iron, or the like: therefore such originally must be the signification of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : (this doth not 〈◊〉 to a confounding it with
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) and though we had no examples of such use of the word, yet the reason was not thereupon to be denyed, but by him who could thinke that no word hath lost it's right signification, and is used onely (by the Authours we have, although neither the Doctor nor I have read all them) in it's Analogicall signification. This I shall not now doubt to call (as Sal •• us doth the like upon every occasion) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . This is the
same argument which Mr. Hobs doth imply in his defense, when he brings an example out of Aristophan: in Ravis. Act, 5. 〈◊〉 . 5. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , &c. The old commentator upon the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 saith thus, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for the (Adimantus) was not a Citizen. I hope the Commentator doth not here mock Aristophanes for jumbling
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 together for want of understanding Greek. No, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
signifies the same, save that, for branding I seldome read 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , As for my part I never read it, but in Scholiasts, or the like Grammarians.

The Doctor replyes nothing to the argument, only the instance (for proof of what I could have cited sorty Authors more, and did therefore suppose it as granted:) he saith that when he read those words, he took them to prove the contrary. If 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 were all one, where was the mistake? What need the Apology, that he (Adimantus, who did not speak pure Greek, but said 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) was a forreigner?

Justly did Mr. Hobs complaine that you presumed too much upon your first cogitations, that you wanted reading in Greek Authours, and did too much trust to your dictionaries! He that reades this passage (I have related all the Doctor saith, and in his own words) would think; That the Doctor had READ the place, That ADIMANTUS spake. That he MISTOOK
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
for
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that use of the word not being pure Greek. And lastly, That the Scholiast makes an APOLOGY for that mistake of his in these words,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for he was a forreigner. But I who know that neither did Adimantus speak; neither was there any mistake committed; nor any Apology made by the Scholiast, do think I may conclude the Doctor never READ the place: or else I do not know what to think.

Pluto being to let Aeschy • us return to Athe • s with Becchus, he tells him what he must do when he comes thither; that he should give good advice to the Citizens; and carry that [Rope, or the like] to Cleph • n Myrmex, Nicomachus, and Arche ••••• , and bid them come quickly to him, without stay, adding
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

If they do not come forthwith, he will brand them, and put them in bonds together with Adimantus, and so send them to Mell. Now this punishment of branding being novel at Athens and not inflicted upon any Citizen, but upon the
〈◊〉
after their second revolt, (whence ca •• e the Proverb in Athens 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) and possibly upon some others that were not Natives of Attica. Plato seems to hold forth this in his Book de legib. l. 8. (wherein he doth so give laws, that he hath an eye still upon those of his own countrey.) he supposes no Citizen will commit Sacriledge, and for other 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : the 〈◊〉
lest any should wonder how Cleoph • n and Adimantus & the rest who were in great power at Athens should be stigmatized, he tels us expresly of Adimantus,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Now that Cleoph • n was so too, the same Scholiast doth expressely say in his comment upon the following Chorni, and I think the poet doth in • end that not onely he, but the rest were so, when he praye • that the Athenians may have peace, and let Cleoph • n and the rest of these (whom? but them he had spoken of before) 〈…〉 .

did not signifie a visible point.
〈…〉
give him one blow with his wooden Dagger) that what he addeth about Trab • , is no more to the purpose then the Post •
And if he understood what he had already said, I wonder how he could finde no better way to illustrate his thoughts.

What he saith, Fifthly: is but an acquitrance of me (as I already observed) that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
did differ as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
〈◊〉
in his book de A • . calls D ••• critus's
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , of which he thought the soul to consist, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : but those are not visible. Theophrast. de plant. l. 3. c. 15. saith of the bark of the tree, Corylus, that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Here it is a visible sp • t. So Aristot. Hist. An. l. 6. c. 7. distinguishing the Birds 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , saith •
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
•
Which distinction he is so far from having understood, that it hath cast him into further absurdities. What • e in conclusion after t • , that it is now contended for, that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
be all one; it is false, as I have shewed.

I have already given an account of his Sixthly: He had well read and considered the place in Stephen: yet Stephen saith not what the Doctor saith; he doth not say that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is sometimes put for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . He saith 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifieth in Hesiod Puncta five macules quibus aliquid variatum est atque distinctum qu • st panctis. But that it is put for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , sometimes, or often, he saith not a word. But St! the Doctor observes! what? that he doth not say 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is sometimes used for
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , (but I have proved it) or is the same with
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Which latter, if it be taken absolutely, no body asserted: but take it secundum quid, and he that quoted 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in the text of Hesiod, quoted
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in the Scholiast: that is, he expounded 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in the place, by 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; which is to say, that as Hesiod used
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
• or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , so the Scholiast die use 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , but not for a mark with an hot iron.

In the place out of 2 Macat. 9. 11. he saith it is possible that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 may imply somewhat of pricking, but not burning, nor with an hot iron. But I would not have him confound 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 with 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : the latter imports only action of pricking (as when we we mark somewhat) but the latter doth imply the mark it self. And the sense of the Author requires it (in my judgement) to be expounded by burning (rather then any other way) since Antiochus dyed of an er •• tion of Wormes: and I am sure they who 〈◊〉 troubled with the Worm (which in the North often breeds in their knees under the Pan •
tella) complain that their torments are as if they were burnt with hot irons. That of Pans • ni • s doth not mention an hot iron; no more doth any place he shall bring for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : yet the general consent of men hath rendred 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 by nota i ••• ta: and however
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in there put for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and the use of any other way of stigmatizing them by hot irons, I do not remember to have read, in these dayes. Appi • n. b • l. civil. saith, that the servant of Restio was
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and call the mark 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : Martial saith, he was fro •• notarus, which are generally understood of his being burnt; and the Authours thought they had by that word expressed as much as Velarius Meximms who saith l. 6. c. 8. that he was Inexpiabili liter ••••
• old per 〈◊〉 oris cont •• sliam inustus. Or Austi ••
(whom I cite, though no Grocian) is reported to say, Pri • s sub Restione
〈…〉
Dion Ca ••• es and his Epitomiser Xiphilin say of the same, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

To Diodorus 〈◊〉
he replyes that it is not said to have been done with an hot iron: which is true, and would have been, if it had been 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That servile was brake out when 〈◊〉 was ingaged at the 〈◊〉 of
〈◊〉 : and I do not know that men were any other way marked at that time, but by hot irons: And men did therefore speak more
negligently, because that another way was not then in use; nor a long time after the decay of the Roman Empire: they did matricula ••
Souldiers, and brand them first with Iron, and after infuse with a Stylus or the like, a thick gross sort of Ink: which was thereupon called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Cedren: not that the brand was performed by pricking, but because it was afterwards so pointed with Ink, because that they had learn'd a way of taking them out otherwise.
div.q: Stigmata nec vas •• delebis Cian ••• s ar • e.
div.p:
He addes further, that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (in the plural) are used as equipollent to one 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
(in the singular.) But this conjecture must not overthrow my opinion, since there were more
〈◊〉
then one imprinted: yea more stigmata,, as upon the Hand, Back, Shoulders, &c. And this was not only the practice of the Assyrian (and Egyptian) Priests, and Thracians, (where it was honourable) but Grecians and Romans: (as every one knowes) and even in that place 〈◊〉 renders it Certe per inustionem corporum notae inprimebantur. But could not the Doctor have found a more easie and obvious interpretation, that they had all but one 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or mark to shew whose servants they were; but they had several
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , upon their bodies. But it is further observable that Isidorus Orig. l. 20. c. 16. speaking de instrumentis equorum, where it was most requisite for him to fix the terms of art upon their right significations, faith 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Character, est ferrum
〈◊〉 , quo nota pecudibus inuruntur. The mark it self is called by Anacreon
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Hesychius calls them 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

Now follows Zonaras, whose two texts compared together do sufficiently evince, that what he meant by 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he intended by 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . In both places he speaks of more then one, and therefore 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
is not necessarily restrained to signifie the pricks; and in the same text he seemed to me, (nor to me only, but also to Lips • us) to render 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 by 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . There is no mark with an hot iron: it is right, but that is presumed, as in Rbodigimus, when he explains stigmatias by notis inustus. But the Doctor can construe Greek! 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
[he made points or pricks in their faces] 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (and put
〈◊〉 , upon these pricks] 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or characters which consisted of those 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , made so many letters)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
(which Letters made up these lambicks) After this exposition (you see the Doctor can not only glosse upon 1 Time 2. 15. he can make a Nose of Wax of other Books too) the Doctor asks, What serves all this to prove? I answer, that it still proves that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 might be made without an hot iron (if these marks were so imprinted.) But why doth he render
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 by the pricked them in the face? Is that the signification of the word? can he
• hew an example of that use of it? Is there any other term in Greek for to signifie to brand, then 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is more usual? is not taken for a Synonyma with
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ? Is it not still expounded by the Latins inuro, inscribe
• tis compungo? I know not what might occasion him so to render it, unlesse because I had taught him the difference betwize 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , was like that of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; he like a bad Scholar imagines the stigmata to have been made up of actual points: (yes! Comma's, and Colons!) just as a Letter (in ordinary speech, for I do not now intend to dispute Philosiphically) is supposed to be made up of actual lines! which is not true of many, and whele it is, that is not the thing begets the appellation, but the conceipt we have thereof. Either it must have been so; or that Latin phrase notis
〈◊〉
hath deceived him! for that expression may be verified of your Sheep or
〈◊〉 . I finde also stigmate p ••• cti in Petr •• ius: from whence I may conclude, In the Doctors way, that stigma was but a point. There remains nothing but that the Author of that interpretation urge that confodio is to run through with a Spade: and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
to prick with a Needle, or the like in Appian, and Zosi •• s, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 several
times in the Septuagint.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ! The Doctor was not content to give us a new Gloss; he varies the old Text. His 〈◊〉 (forsooth,) tells him 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
is a Verb contract, and therefore it ought to be contractedly read 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Surely he read this place too! But the Author is not bound up by those novel rules, but writes with that latitude, which frequent precedents do) justifie unto him, notwithstanding our Critick. But letting the Text stand as it does, why may we not think he did 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as well as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Moreover, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 will hear as large a signification as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for so I read in Epictetus c. 61. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . If in your shoes, you look for more then the securing of your feet from external inconveniences, then you become ob •• xious to fashions, the gilded, the purple, and the party-coloured shoe. Eustath. in Homer. And in another place Theodora that Empress tells one of those same Stigmatical Monks, when she looked upon 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , &c. which 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifies to engrave as it were with a Chissel. I confesse that if the Doctor had shewed that ever the Ancients did so brand people as to make the up letters of actual points placed in such a series as to make up Letters, he had weakned the authority of the place: or if he had shewed how that after Constantine (upon a good reason •
because he would not have the image of God defaced in man,) prohibited the stigmatizing of any in the face, that upon the renewing of the punishment they altered the manner, it had been something, but since they were
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, notis barbaricis inscripta, or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , inci • a, (which to interpret as done by pricks, were strange.) Since there is nothing alledged for the abosishing of the old 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and introducing a new way by pricks (for the performance of it by a Pencil or Pen knife is novel, and of it there is not any mention in the Ancients, that I remember, till after men grew more • ender • spirited) let me enjoy the s • anding meaning: and let 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 refer to the two persons stigmatised. I shall not stand to professe that the way of branding is difficult to explain, because that words are capable of different interpretations; and in this c • le it is impossible to make out the manner thereof beyond exception. That it w •• performed by burning of old there is no doubt:
Vritur ardenti propter duo lintea ferro. Iuvenal.
Signare oportet frontem cali •• forcipa. So No • ius.

And in Greek, Plato calls the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in his T ••• us: Lacian in his Piscator brings in Truth bidding Parre • iades to shave the Pseudo Philosophers beards close, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . I do here conceive that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
and, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifie one and the same thing under several words: and that it was performed with a brand,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and I do not see why we should think that mark of an Ape or Fox to have been made up of several points: yet so the Doctor must construe all the places wherem 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 occ • rres; and after all that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
will be a mark with an hot iron, though not the same with 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which we did never say; nor were we c • ncerned in the 〈◊〉 of Rog •• es, since all that Mr. Hobs said
(and • o the Doctor cites him Dr. Cor. p. 18) was, that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 was a mark with an hot iron, let it be inflicted vpon whom, or what cause you will. How Rogues were

Here it is evident that no mention is made of burning, but it is still supplyed by the
〈◊〉 , and no mention is brought in those times of that other way which I mentioned out of Elias Vinetus performed by the incision of a Pen kni • e, in the dayes concerning which I brought the proof of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . And as for the other marks honorary the Egyptians seem to have imprinted by fire irons only 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , single points: so Prudentius saith it was •• formed acubus minutis stigmendo, not stigmatisando Not do I ever remember that I read of any form those 〈◊〉 marks had: that Stellarum 〈◊〉
in
〈◊〉 , and those Sphragitides may be solved well enough, if, we suppose the management to have been thus; yet Epimenides was 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . As to the number of them, Prudentius and that example of Epimenidet do make it clear they did imp • int many marks▪ yet I do not hear that Pythagoras had more then one, and that on his thi ••
which is the conjecture of an ingenio • s but modern writer. The Assyrians

▪ or • f they had not, yet what is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 when considered simply as a point, may be called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
when considered as figured: And this I say not receding from, but keeping to that distinction which I said was betwixt 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as betwixt 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Yea, the case was so upon other occasions, so as that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 were one and the same thing (under a different notion) as appears from the use of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in Theophrastus, &c. and that of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in Hesiod, Aristotle, &c. I do not think that the pictures of animals which were imprinted on the old Britains ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) will be understood of pointing, or pricking: and if the Doctor should go to any person and bid him write, engrave, carve, cut, &c. his name; I do not think they would so understand the Doctor, as he understands 〈◊〉 . Of▪ the Thracians I can say no more then that they were 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , so Dion Chrysoft.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , so Eustath▪ upon Homer (the Dabe were Virgati, will any expound that of pricks too?) and though the brand were never so great, and shaped, yet it might be said compungi, to be punched, as I observed before. And now I have said not only more then any before me, but what may satisfie one not resolutely contumacious: I have sufficiently evinced that the Doctor was out, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
being a mark with an hot iron: And for what follows, let any man believe that the
• udgement of Marcellus, Stigmata non ta ••
〈◊〉 , qu • m punctis • ariatam super • iciem Graci •• caverunt: which I finde seconded by the attestarion of several Authors (de
〈◊〉
vene • icarum;) let any man believe that that same is against me, that can.

And now I have run through this tedious plece of pedantry: I have not omitted any thing unanswered, that I know: not have I ever imposed upon him any thing, wittingly, which might not be his meaning. I have so examined things, as who should seek truth, and not victory: I have not heaped upon him impertinent contumeli • s; and for telling him what he is (which is no abuse) I think he ought rather to thank me then he angry: I hope he will not hereafter look upon himself in the • al • e glasse of Enco ••
• tick
Letters, but take his length from my measure; and not trouble the world, nor pester his bookes with curiosities in Philology, nor intermeddle with Divinity but confine himself to Symbols, wherein he may do well it is hoped in time, and he will have that happiness to meet with as few Readers as he doth Auditors. I would advise him to call Mr. Hobs his book, Stigma Hobbianum▪ rather then 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 since all the several points therein discussed and examined amount but to one Stigma: which I here represent. K. I. K. I. And so dismisse him as one of the LITERATI, though not as a Virtuoso.

Thus Sir you see I have vindicated my self, and you, or rather my self to you: I have dealt so with your enemy, that I dare take up the saying of Petronius, Implevi frontem ingentibus literis, & notum epigr amma per totam faciem liberali manu duxi. I hope you will prove hereafter more cautious, then to publish any thing in Philology, since Mar • anus Capella hath left his Mistresse double-beneficed to the Assembly of Divines: and no one is to pretend to Criticisme or any thing of learning but such as are of that Classe: if any man shall presume to call another so, or have any esteem for them, or make honourable mention of them, there shall be aspersions cast upon him, and an Index expurg • torius, whereby shall be blotted out all those honourable mentions of any dissenter: In like manner as their Predecessour, the Pope (the power is the same whether divided, or united) expunged the titles of doctus, and eruditus out of the Catholick writers where they were bestowed upon the Protestants. I shall now conclude with the diver • i • ement of some Poetry, the Authors whereof I am not bound to declare; and desire you would finde out some other way hereafter, whereby I may shew you how much I am and desire to be

closer.signed: your most humble and most affectionate Servant, H. Stubbe.
